Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Immersive Augmented Reality Landscape Viewer for Public Space Deployment
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will explore the technical, commercial, and educational potentials of bringing augmented reality binocular kiosks to public locations and their ability to create lasting impact on the public's understanding of a place. The proposed research and development phase will focus on the deployment and field testing of a collection of prototypes with partner locations, and examine their efficacy at engaging and informing visitors of those sites. The broader significance of the project is the development of an information device and ecosystem that gives the public a better understanding of notable places and the greater physical world. Deployments will be able to visualize a variety of site-specific data, from environmental conditions, to geological formations and landmark navigation. Potential revenue can be generated in partnership with locations, allowing for sustainable long-term engagements between the project and a site. Direct economic impact is brought to a location and its surroundings through increased foot traffic and the encouragement of additional exploration of a space.


The innovation being proposed is stereoscopic wide-field-of-view see-through augmented reality viewers in the form of landscape binocular kiosks designed to give public spaces a way to engage visitors with the natural, scientific, and historic features of that location. In addition to displaying immersive media experiences optically overlaid onto a view of the real world, this project creates a distributed media network on that location to share data and content for remote viewing and analysis. Goals and scope of research include durability testing of the devices in prolonged public exposure, effectiveness of the user interface and software tools, understanding the range and bandwidth of device-to-device communication, and optimization of the optical, electromechanical, and sensor components. Methods and approaches will include the field testing of prototype units with partner locations, and using survey and analysis techniques to evaluate the overall quantitative and qualitative efficacy of the intervention at those sites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Augmented reality is rapidly becoming a new paradigm in computing and interactive media, with significant investments being made by most of the major technology firms. The ability to provide real-time contextual information in a way that is spatially tied to what's around us can give deeper insights to the natural world, enhance our ability to perform difficult tasks, and convey complex information in a more intuitive way. However, these technologies can be challenging to implement in public contexts like museums or sites of natural wonder, where durability, reliability, and user throughput are critical to their effectiveness. Mobile phone experiences require compatible devices, waiting on app downloads, and increased battery drain.  Augmented reality headsets are expensive, have limited field-of-view, and bring along operational and maintenance challenges when loaned out publicly.

This SBIR Phase I project explored the technical, commercial, and educational potentials of bringing augmented reality pedestal binocular kiosks, known as Perceptoscopes, to public locations and their ability to create lasting impact on the understanding of a place. By focusing on being a durable public kiosk, Perceptoscope creates a frictionless way to engage a variety of visitors without the imposition of requiring a personal device. Through these deployments, augmented reality acts as a service provided by a location, rather than an ability of an individual user.

Research focused on readying Perceptoscope prototypes and experiences for a series of technical and observational field tests in partnership with La Brea Tar Pits (LBTP), an ice-age fossil research site and highly active public space. Technical accomplishments during this research included iteration and refinement of the system's optics, electronics, mechanical engineering, and software development kit. Industrial designs were finalized, and the overall results of these technical goals leave the project ready for scalable production and distribution to partner organizations. 

Alongside this process, Perceptoscope facilitated the creation of augmented reality experiences designed for these field tests in partnership with the Exhibitions department at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County (NHM), the parent organization to the Tar Pits. 

Working with NHM's Director of Evaluation and Museum Impact, an observational research study was designed to understand natural behaviors and interactions around unattended Perceptoscopes at La Brea Tar Pits. A unit was placed in a predetermined area, and allowed for users to see and interact with a variety of ice-age animals that once roamed the Tar Pits site.

Observations recorded included demographic data, social behaviors, and session data logged by onboard sensors. General findings indicate significant organic engagement throughout the time deployed, with crowds often forming to share their experience with one another. Demographic trends showed consistent engagement across all age groups, with particularly high engagement by elementary aged children.

Results of the field research demonstrated Perceptoscope's ability to positively impact visitor engagement with a place. When properly channeled towards the mission of a site like a museum, Perceptoscope deployments, and other public augmented reality interventions, can open new channels of communications and education to visitors at large.
